title: TheoremExplainAgent: Towards Multimodal Explanations for LLM Theorem Understanding
author: Max Ku (University of Waterloo), Thomas Chong (Votee AI), Jonathan Leung (University of Waterloo), Krish Shah (University of Waterloo), Alvin Yu (Votee AI), Wenhu Chen (University of Waterloo), ...
relevance_why: The paper explores generative models for visual explanations in theorem understanding, which can inform methods for multimodal data synthesis in audio processing tasks, enhancing interpretability and teaching tools.
background: This study addresses the need for AI systems to explain complex theorems effectively through video, integrating text and visuals to enhance understanding.
contribution: The paper introduces TheoremExplainAgent, a generative AI framework capable of creating explanatory videos for theorems, achieving success in producing long-form content that incorporates visual and audio elements.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous models predominantly focused on text-based reasoning and lacked structured visual explanation capabilities.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by integrating a planning agent and a coding agent to generate comprehensive explanation videos, demonstrating enhanced explanatory power through visual elements.

key_innovation: The use of multiple specialized agents to autonomously generate high-quality, long-form explanatory videos that combine textual and visual narratives.
real_world_impact: This approach could improve educational tools in STEM fields by facilitating better understanding of complex concepts, potentially transforming how students learn mathematics and science.
limitations: The video quality and layout of visual elements remain issues, with minor inaccuracies observed during evaluations.

new_terms.TheoremExplainAgent: **TheoremExplainAgent** is a novel AI system designed to generate explanatory videos for complex mathematical theorems, leveraging both language and visual modeling for better understanding.

open_sourcing: TheoremExplainBench will be released on Huggingface dataset with MIT licence.
